data.title: Catherine Rose and Don Glendenning are TACA’s 2015 Silver Cup honorees
data.meta_description: They’ll be honored for the contributions to local arts groups at a luncheon March 5.
data.text:
Catherine Marcus Rose and Don M. Glendenning will be TACA's 2015 Silver Cup Award honorees.

Founded in 1976 by former Mayor Annette Strauss, the Silver Cup recognizes one man and one woman each year for contributions to the arts in Dallas.

The TACA Silver Cup Award Luncheon will be held March 5 at the Hilton Anatole, chaired by Jennifer Karol and Karen Pollock.

Mary McDermott Cook and Margaret McDermott are the honorary chairs.

Rose is a Dallas native who has been a trustee of the Dallas Museum of Art since 2001. TACA organizers said she and her husband, Will Rose, have been active with the DMA since 1994, when they were married in the museum. The have supported education, exhibition and acquisition initiatives and she was co-chair of the museum's Campaign for a New Century, which raised over $185 million. Rose has also been on the advisory board of Booker T. Washington High School for the Performing and Visual Arts.

Rose is board chair of The Lamplighter School and on the advisory board of Teach for America Dallas Fort Worth. She's a member of the executive committee of Southwestern Medical Foundation, Charter 100 and the Dallas Assembly.

A graduate of Harvard with a bachelor's degree in fine arts, Rose collects 20th century photography, contemporary art and design with her husband. The couple has three sons.

Glendenning, a corporate and securities lawyer, is managing partner of the Dallas office of Locke Lord LLP, where he has practiced since 1979, right after his graduation from Stanford Law School.

He is president of the Human Rights Initiative of North Texas, chairman of the Thanks-Giving Foundation and a director of the Dallas Holocaust Museum/Center for Education and Tolerance.

Glendenning is a director of the Parkland Foundation and co-chair of the $150 million philanthropic campaign for the new Parkland hospital.

He has been a director of TACA and is now on the boards of the Dallas Theater Center and the SMU Meadows School.

He and his wife, Carol Glendenning, have been married for 35 years.

To learn more about TACA, go to taca-arts.org or call 214-520-3930.
